title: How to Make and Freeze Baby Food

steps.headline: Prepare fresh fruits.
steps.description: Ripe fruit such as bananas, prunes, cantaloupe, apricots and peaches are all types of ideal fruit you can freeze without having to cook them first.

steps.headline: Cook fruits with a harder texture.
steps.description: Fruits such as pears and apples need to be boiled for 2 to 3 minutes or until the fruit is soft enough to stick a fork through it.

steps.headline: Cook vegetables such as peas, carrots, sweet potatoes, green beans, squash and spinach by baking, boiling, or steaming.
Feed your baby liver and well-cooked, unsalted meats.
steps.description: Liver is the easiest meat to blend and is rich in iron.

steps.headline: Mash food using a fork or similar utensil.
steps.description: Whether you are preparing soft raw fruit such as bananas or cooked vegetables such as peas, a fork is usually the easiest way to mash the food.

steps.headline: Use a blender.
steps.description: Cut your baby food into chunk sizes that work best in your blender and blend until it reaches your desired consistency.

steps.headline: Use the straining method.
steps.description: Using a sieve or a strainer, you can push your baby's food through with a spoon until the results are no longer lumpy.

steps.headline: Chop foods finely with a knife.
steps.description: Using an ideal knife for chopping, chop or dice baby food into sections small enough for them to eat without complications.

parts.name: Decide on a Freezer Storing Method

steps.headline: Transfer the baby food to a jar that is freezable.
Stick the jar in the freezer.
Wait for baby food to freeze.
Use ice-cube trays with lids.
steps.description: Ice-cube trays have convenient serving sizes and often a single cube is enough to feed your baby. As your baby grows older, you may increase their serving size to 2 cubes. Ice-cube trays with lids will also help protect your baby food from freezer burn or odors from other food.

steps.headline: Use freezer bags or storage bags with zip-tops.
steps.description: Zip-top bags are a safe way to protect your food from freezer burn, odors, and are easily disposable.

steps.headline: Use the baking sheet method.
steps.description: Although using a cookie sheet or baking sheet may take up lots of room in your freezer, you can drop mounds of prepared baby food on them. Make sure you cover the baby food with food-safe wrap to prevent freezer burn.

text: Select Foods Prepare fresh fruits. Ripe fruit such as bananas, prunes, cantaloupe, apricots and peaches are all types of ideal fruit you can freeze without having to cook them first. Cook fruits with a harder texture. Fruits such as pears and apples need to be boiled for 2 to 3 minutes or until the fruit is soft enough to stick a fork through it. Cook vegetables such as peas, carrots, sweet potatoes, green beans, squash and spinach by baking, boiling, or steaming.  Feed your baby liver and well-cooked, unsalted meats. Liver is the easiest meat to blend and is rich in iron. Choose a Puree Method Mash food using a fork or similar utensil. Whether you are preparing soft raw fruit such as bananas or cooked vegetables such as peas, a fork is usually the easiest way to mash the food. Use a blender. Cut your baby food into chunk sizes that work best in your blender and blend until it reaches your desired consistency. Use the straining method. Using a sieve or a strainer, you can push your baby's food through with a spoon until the results are no longer lumpy. Chop foods finely with a knife. Using an ideal knife for chopping, chop or dice baby food into sections small enough for them to eat without complications. Decide on a Freezer Storing Method Transfer the baby food to a jar that is freezable.  Leave the cap on loosely.  Stick the jar in the freezer.  Wait for baby food to freeze.  Use ice-cube trays with lids. Ice-cube trays have convenient serving sizes and often a single cube is enough to feed your baby. As your baby grows older, you may increase their serving size to 2 cubes. Ice-cube trays with lids will also help protect your baby food from freezer burn or odors from other food. Use freezer bags or storage bags with zip-tops. Zip-top bags are a safe way to protect your food from freezer burn, odors, and are easily disposable. Use the baking sheet method. Although using a cookie sheet or baking sheet may take up lots of room in your freezer, you can drop mounds of prepared baby food on them. Make sure you cover the baby food with food-safe wrap to prevent freezer burn. Finished.
